abstract.t: Privacy is a concept that has been debated and argued throughout the last few millennia by all manner of people. Its most striking feature is that nobody seems able to agree upon a precise definition of what it actually is. In order to discuss privacy in any meaningful way a tightly defined context needs to be elucidated. The specific context of privacy used within this document is that of "personal data" for usage in Internet protocols. Personal data refers to any information relating to a data subject; a data subject is an identified natural person or a natural person who can be identified, directly or indirectly.

A lot of work within the IETF involves defining protocols that can potentially transport (either explicitly or implicitly) personal data. Data minimization is a strategy for privacy protection and impacts the design of Internet protocols. Therefore this document aims to establish a basic lexicon around privacy so that IETF contributors who wish to discuss privacy considerations within their work can do so using terminology consistent across the area.
Note: This document is discussed at https://www.ietf.org/mailman/listinfo/ietf-privacy

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Privacy is a concept that has been debated and argued throughout the last few millennia by all manner of people, including philosophers, psychologists, lawyers, and more recently, computer scientists. Its most striking feature is that nobody seems able to agree upon a precise definition of what it actually is. Every individual, every group, and every culture have their own different views and preconceptions about the concept - some mutually complimentary, some distinctly different. However, it is generally (but not unanimously!) agreed that the protection of privacy is "A Good Thing" and often, people only realize what it was when they feel that they have lost it.

In order to discuss privacy in any meaningful way a tightly defined context needs to be elucidated. The specific context of privacy used within this document is that of "personal data" for usage in Internet protocols. A lot of work within the IETF involves defining protocols that can potentially transport personal data and can therefore either, by dint of design decisions when creating them, enable either privacy protection or result in privacy breaches. Protocol architects often do not assume a specific relationship between the identifiers and data elements communicated in protocols and the human using the software. However, a protocol may help or simplify the re-identification of a natural person by the choice of their identifiers and other state that is established and communicated. The ability to combine information over time and from various sources simplifies the re-identification and profiling.

Work in this area of privacy and privacy protection over the last few decades has centered on the idea of data minimization; it uses terminologies such as anonymity, pseudonymity, unlinkability, and undetectability. These terms are often used in discussions about the privacy properties of systems.

The objective of data minimization is to minimize the risk of misusing data by omitting privacy-relevant information where possible. Data minimization aims to enhance privacy in cases where personal data is used since it inherently provides some linkability. Other techniques have been proposed and implemented that aim to enhance privacy by providing misinformation (inaccurate or erroneous information, provided usually without conscious effort to mislead or deceive) or disinformation (deliberately false or distorted information provided in order to mislead or deceive). However, these techniques are out of scope for this document.

This document aims to establish a basic lexicon around privacy so that IETF contributors who wish to discuss privacy considerations within their work (see ) can do so using terminology consistent across areas. Note that it does not attempt to define all aspects of privacy terminology, rather it just establishes terms to some of the most common ideas and concepts.

list.t: Personal data refers to any information relating to a data subject.
A data subject is an identified natural person or a natural person who can be identified, directly or indirectly.

Observer - A party who acts with malicious intent to compromise an information system. The observer may not only be an entity that is external to the analyzed message interaction, such as an eavesdropper, but the observer is, in many cases, one of the communication partners. We assume that the observer uses all information available to infer (probabilities of) his items of interest (IOIs). These IOIs may be attributes (and their values) of personal data, or may be actions such as who sent, or who received, which messages. When necessary for the understanding of the definition we qualify the capabilities of the observer in the communication architecture. Note that privacy violations are not only caused with malicious intent. Many of them are, such as a lost CDROM containing personal data or an email addressed to patients with the addresses in the TO rather than the BCC field, outside the realm of the IETF and therefore not considered here.

Initiator and recipient - For two party protocol interactions we use the terms initiator and recipient. The initiator starts a communication interaction and the recipient is the intended communication endpoint. This particular terminology is used to highlight that many protocols utilize bidirectional communication where both ends send and receive data.

The Identity Provider (IdP) is an entity that has a relationship with a data subject (usually connected to the organisation operating the entity) and is responsible for providing authentication and authorisation information to Relying Parties (RP). To facilitate this the entity will usually go through a process of verifying the person's identity and issuing them a set of credentials. Note that practically each of these functions (identity verification, credential issuing, providing authentication assertions, providing authorisation assertions, etc) may performed by separate entities; for the purposes of this document, however, we assume a single entity is performing all of them, without loss of generality.

The Relying Party (RP) is an entity that relies on authentication and authorisation provided by an identity provider regarding a person, typically to process a transaction or grant access to information or a system.

section.title: Identifiability
section.t: An identity is any subset of attribute values of an individual person which sufficiently identifies this individual person within a given context. So usually there is no such thing as "the identity", but several of them.
The following sub-sections define terms around different ways of avoiding identifiability.

section.title: Anonymity

list.t: Anonymity of a subject means that the observer cannot sufficiently identify the subject within a set of subjects, the anonymity set.

section.t: To enable anonymity of a subject, there always has to be an appropriate set of subjects with potentially the same attributes. The set of all possible subjects is known as the anonymity set, and membership of this set may vary over time.

The set of possible subjects depends on the knowledge of the observer. Thus, anonymity is relative with respect to the observer. Therefore, an initiator may be anonymous (initiator anonymity) only within a set of potential initiators - their initiator anonymity set - which itself may be a subset of all subjects who may send a message. Conversely a recipient may be anonymous (receipient anonymity) only within a set of potential receipients - their receipient anonymity set. Both anonymity sets may be disjoint, may overlap, or may be the same.

list.t: As an example consider RFC 3325 (P-Asserted-Identity, PAI) , an extension for the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), that allows subjects, such as a VoIP caller, to instruct an intermediary he or she trusts not to populate the SIP From header field with its authenticated and verified identity. The recipient of the call, as well as any other entity outside the data subjects's trust domain, would therefore only learn that the SIP message (typically a SIP INVITE) was sent with a header field 'From: "Anonymous" <sip:anonymous@anonymous.invalid>' rather than the subject's address-of-record, which is typically thought of as the "public address" of the user, i.e., the data subject. When PAI is used the subject becomes anonymous within the initiator anonymity set that is populated by every subject making use of that specific intermediary.

Note: This example assumes that other personal data cannot be inferred from the other SIP protocol payloads, which is a useful assumption to be made in the analysis of one specific protocol extension but not for analysis of an entire architecture.

section.title: Pseudonymity

list.t: A pseudonym is an identifier of a subject other than one of the subject's real names. An identifier, as defined in , is "a lexical token that names entities".

section.t: In the context of IETF protocols almost all identifiers are pseudonyms since there is typically no requirement to use real names in protocols. However, in certain scenario it is reasonable to assume that real names will be used and it will be worthwhile to point out this circumstance.

For Internet protocols it is important whether protocols allow identifiers to be changed without human interaction, what the lifetime of the pseudonyms are, to whom they get exposed, how subjects are able to control disclosure, and how often they can be changed over time (and what the consequences are when they are regularly changed). These aspects are described in .

Achieving anonymity, unlinkability, and maybe undetectability may enable the extreme of data minimization. Unfortunately, it would also prevent a certain class of useful two-way communication scenarios. Therefore, for many applications, we need to accept a certain amount of linkability and detectability while attempting to retain unlinkability between the subject and their transactions. This is achieved through appropriate kinds of pseudonymous identifiers. These identifiers are then often used to refer to established state or are used for access control purposes, see .

The term "real name is the antonym to "pseudonym". There may be multiple real names over a lifetime -- in particular legal names. For example, a human being may possess the names which appear on their birth certificate or on other official identity documents issued by the State; for a legal person the name under which it operates and which is registered in official registers (e.g., commercial register or register of associations). A human being's real name typically comprises their given name and a family name. Note that from a mere technological perspective it cannot always be determined whether an identifier of a subject is a pseudonym or a real name.
Additional useful terms are:

list.t: The "holder" of the pseudonym is the subject to whom the pseudonym refers.
A subject is "pseudonymous" if a pseudonym is used as identifier instead of one of its real names.
Pseudonymity is the state of remaining pseudonymous through the use of pseudonyms as identifiers.

section.t: initiator pseudonymity is defined as the initiator being pseudonymous, recipient pseudonymity is defined as the recipient being pseudonymous.

list.t: Identity confidentiality means that any party other than the recipient cannot sufficiently identify the subject within the anonymity set. In comparison to anonymity and pseudonymity, identity confidentiality is concerned about eavesdroppers and intermediaries.

As an example consider the network access authentication procedures utilizing the Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP) . EAP includes an identity exchange where the Identity Response is primarily used for routing purposes and selecting which EAP method to use. Since EAP Identity Requests and Responses are sent in cleartext, eavesdroppers and intermediaries along the communication path between the EAP peer and the EAP server can snoop on the identity. To address such a treat the user's identity, as discussed in RFC 4282 , can be hidden against these observers with the cryptography support by EAP methods. Certain EAP methods have been designed and identity confidentiality has become a recommended design criteria, see . EAP-AKA , for example, protects the EAP peer's identity against passive adversaries by utilizing temporal identities. EAP-IKEv2 is an example of an EAP method that offers protection against active observers with regard to the subjects' identity.

section.title: Unlinkability

list.t: Unlinkability of two or more Items Of Interest (e.g., subjects, messages, actions, ...) means that within a particular set of information, the observer cannot distinguish whether these IOIs are related or not (with a high enough degree of probability to be useful).

section.t: Unlinkability of two (or more) messages may of course depend on whether their content is protected against the observer. In the cases where this is not true, messages may only be unlinkable if we assume that the observer is not able to infer information about the initiator or receipient from the message content itself. It is worth noting that even if the content itself does not betray linkable information explicitly, deep semantical analysis of a message sequence can often detect certain characteristics which link them together, e.g., similarities in structure, style, use of some words or phrases, consistent appearance of some grammatical errors, etc.

The unlinkability property can be considered as a more "fine-grained" version of anonymity since there are many more relations where unlinkability might be an issue than just the relation of "anonymity" between subjects and IOIs. As such, it may sometimes be necessary to explicitly state to which attributes anonymity refers to (beyond the subject to IOI relationship). An observer might be able to link various messages while not necessarily weakening anonymity of the particular subject. As an example an observer, in spite of being able to link all encrypted messages in a set of transactions, does not learn the identify of the subject who is the source of the transactions.
There are several items of terminology highly related to unlinkability:

list.t: We use the term "profiling" to mean learning information about a particular subject by linking together separate pieces of information referring to the same data subject. For example, if an observer concludes that a subject plays a specific computer game, reads specific news article on a website, and uploads certain videos, then the subject's activities have been profiled, even if the observer is unable to identify that specific subject.

"Relationship anonymity" of a pair of subjects means that initiator and receipient (or each recipient in case of multicast) are unlinkable. The classical MIX-net without dummy traffic is one implementation with just this property: The observer sees who sends messages when, and who receives messages when, but cannot figure out who is sending messages to whom.

"Recipient identity anonymity" refers to the property where the recipient's identity is kept anonymous from the initiator. For example, consider an identity management scenario, which is a three party scenario, where an identity provider, who manages the data subjects credentials and attributes, shall not observe activities of data subjects throughout the Internet as they interact with relying parties.

"initiator identity anonymity" refers to the property where the initiator remains anonymous towards the recipient. Within the identity management scenario the initiator role corresponds to the identity provider and the recipients are the relying parties. As such, with this property a relying party will not determine the identity provider used by a data subject for a given transaction.

"Unlinkable sessions" is the property of a protocol that prevents an eavesdropper from associating one protocol run to an earlier one.
This term is useful for cases where a sequence of interactions between an initiator and a recipient is necessary for the application logic rather than a single-shot message. We refer to this as a session. When doing an analysis with respect to unlinkability we compare this session to a sequence of sessions to determine whether or not they are linkable.

We use the term "fingerprinting" to refer to any parameter (or set of parameters) that an observer can observe for the purpose of re-recognition. Fingerprinting is a form of tracking by associating activities of a communication software at different times, potentially with different communication partners, but without explicitly sharing state information (as it would be the case with cookies ). For example, the Panopticlick project by the Electronic Frontier Foundation uses parameters an HTTP-based Web browser shares with sites it visits to determine the uniqueness of the browser .

section.title: Undetectability

list.t: Undetectability of an item of interest (IOI) means that the observer cannot sufficiently distinguish whether it exists or not.

section.t: In contrast to anonymity and unlinkability, where the IOI is protected indirectly through protection of the IOI's relationship to a subject or other IOI, undetectability is the direct protection of an IOI. For example, undetectability can be regarded as a possible and desirable property of steganographic systems.
If we consider messages as IOIs, then undetectability means that messages are not sufficiently discernible from, e.g., "random noise".

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document introduces terminology for talking about privacy within IETF specifications. Since privacy protection often relies on security mechanisms then this document is also related to security in its broader context.
